attributes.title: TDT Sandwich
attributes.description: An open source and modular system for heating samples with dry heat at a controlled heating rate.

summary.value: This registration contains the bill of materials, design files, and software for the TDT Sandwich system for submission to the HardwareX journal.

attributes.title: An Arabic Dataset Used for Article Headline Generation Using Deep Learning Techniques

q1.value: The Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory (BESSI 1.0): Measurement properties and links with student outcomes.

q2.value: Madison Sewell, Christopher Napolitano, Christopher J. Soto, Brent Roberts

q3.value:
This study is designed to examine the basic measurement properties of the Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory, Version 1.0 (BESSI 1.0), as well as age differences in BESSI scores and associations of the BESSI with student outcomes. Our key research questions are:

1) How internally consistent are the BESSI facet scales?
2) How well-differentiated are the BESSI facet scales?
3) Does the BESSI have a clear multidimensional structure?
4) Are there mean-level age differences in the BESSI facets and domains?
5) Does the BESSI relate with student outcomes in conceptually meaningful ways?

q4.value:
1) We expect that alpha reliabilities for the BESSI 1.0 facet scales will average at least .70, and will all be at least .50.
2) We expect that most correlations between BESSI facet scales will be positive (reflecting a positive manifold for BES skills), but less than .90 (indicating that the facets are not entirely redundant).
3) We expect that the BESSI will have a five-dimensional structure when tested using exploratory factor analysis, with domains reflecting social engagement, cooperation, self-regulation, emotional resilience, and intellectual engagement.
4) We expect that scores on BESSI domains and facets will generally increase by participant grade level/age.
5) We expect that the BESSI domains will relate with student outcomes in a number of conceptually-meaningful ways. See the attached pdf for specific predictions.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is an observational study without any between-subject or within-subject manipulations.

q9.value: This observational study does not include multiple conditions. Therefore, the only element of randomization is that, for most measures, the item order is randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: CLRN expects a sample size of approximately 1,000 participants for this study.

q14.value: This sample size would provide 88.8% power to detect a small effect (r = .10), and greater than 99.9% power to detect a medium-sized (r = .30) or large  (r = .50) effect, using two-tailed tests at the .05

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above

question.value: This observational study does not include any manipulated variables.

The main predictors will be the 32 BESSI 1.0 facets, and the five expected domains derived from these facets.

The main outcomes will be life satisfaction (measured using Satisfaction With Life Scale); popularity (measured using an item from the Behavior Report Form); social status (measured using an item adapted from Anderson, John, Keltner, & Kring, 2001); friendship quality (measured using an abbreviated version of the Friendship Qualities Scale); romantic relationship satisfaction (measured using two items from the Dyadic Adjustment Scale); parental relationship quality (measured using six items adapted from the Dunedin Study); academic engagement measured using an abbreviated version of the Engagement versus Disaffection with Learning scale); exercise (measured using the Godin Leisure Time Exercise Questionnaire); volunteerism (measured using four items from Carlo, Okun, Knight, & de Guzman, 2005); and occupational interests (measured using the O*Net Mini Interest Profiler), as well as student information system data on attendance, report card grades, and discipline provided by the CLRN.

The main covariates are student grade level and gender.

The 32 BESSI facet scales will be scored from their constituent items using simple item aggregation. See the attached Excel file for a list of items and scale assignments.

Domain scales for the BESSI will be derived from principal components analyses (PCAs) and exploratory factor analyses (EFAs) of the BESSI facet scales. The assignment of facets to domains will depend on the PCA and EFA results, as well as conceptual considerations, and is therefore exploratory. However, all decisions about assigning the BESSI facets to domains will be made before we conduct any analyses to test associations between the BESSI scores and student outcomes. After assigning facets to domains, we will derive two sets of domain scores: one from simple aggregation of the facet scores, and one from factor scores for a selected PCA or EFA of the facet scales.

All outcome measures are previously published, and we will compute outcome scores following the published scoring instructions for each measure. For most outcome measures, scale scores are computed using simple item aggregation.

1) Internal consistency of the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Cronbach’s alpha reliability coefficient.
2) Differentiation between the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients.
3) The multidimensional structure of the BESSI will be tested using PCAs and EFAs of the 32 BESSI facet scales. These analyses will be repeated using both orthogonal (varimax) and oblique (promax) rotations.
4) Age differences in the BESSI domains and facets will be tested using one-way ANOVAs, with grade level as a fixed factor.
5) Associations of the BESSI domains with student outcomes will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients and multiple regression analyses. In the regression analyses, we will first analyze associations on a domain-by-domain basis, then all BESSI domains will be entered simultaneously as predictors. The correlation and regression analyses will be repeated both with and without gender and grade level as covariates.

q20.value: Number of disciplinary incidents may be transformed to reduce the influence of outliers. All decisions about whether and how to transform this variable will be made after examining its frequency distribution, but before testing its associations with the BESSI domains and facets.

q21.value: All tests will be two-tailed tests using the .05 significance level. To avoid interpreting statistically significant but trivially small effects, interpretation will focus on effect sizes (r/β) of .10 or greater.

q22.value: The study’s survey includes two pairs of attention-check items: one pair near the end of the BESSI, and one pair near the end of the outcome battery. Participants who fail either BESSI attention check item will be excluded from all analyses. Participants who pass both BESSI attention check items, but then fail either outcome attention check item, will be excluded from all analyses of the outcome measures.

q23.value: For participants who pass the relevant attention and completion checks, each missing response will be imputed as the sample’s mean response to that item, rounded to the nearest possible response option.

q24.value:
There may be individual differences in acquiescent response style on the BESSI. We will therefore examine whether accounting for these individual differences (e.g., using within-person centering or random-intercept EFA) affects the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We may use the PCA/EFA results to develop and test confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) models of the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We will examine possible gender differences in the BESSI domains and facets using independent-samples t-tests, as well as two-way ANOVAs with grade level and gender as fixed factors.

We will also examine relations of the BESSI facets with student outcomes using correlation and regression analyses. We will repeat these analyses both with and without grade level and gender as covariates.

4) Age differences in the BESSI domains and facets will be tested using one-way ANOVAs, with grade level as a fixed factor.
5) Associations of the BESSI domains with student outcomes will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients and multiple regression analyses. In the regression analyses, we will first analyze associations on a domain-by-domain basis, then all BESSI domains will be entered simultaneously as predictors. q1.value: The Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory (BESSI 1.0): Measurement properties and links with student outcomes.

q2.value: Madison Sewell, Christopher Napolitano, Christopher J. Soto, Brent Roberts

q3.value:
This study is designed to examine the basic measurement properties of the Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory, Version 1.0 (BESSI 1.0), as well as age differences in BESSI scores and associations of the BESSI with student outcomes. Our key research questions are:

1) How internally consistent are the BESSI facet scales?
2) How well-differentiated are the BESSI facet scales?
3) Does the BESSI have a clear multidimensional structure?
4) Are there mean-level age differences in the BESSI facets and domains?
5) Does the BESSI relate with student outcomes in conceptually meaningful ways?

q4.value:
1) We expect that alpha reliabilities for the BESSI 1.0 facet scales will average at least .70, and will all be at least .50.
2) We expect that most correlations between BESSI facet scales will be positive (reflecting a positive manifold for BES skills), but less than .90 (indicating that the facets are not entirely redundant).
3) We expect that the BESSI will have a five-dimensional structure when tested using exploratory factor analysis, with domains reflecting social engagement, cooperation, self-regulation, emotional resilience, and intellectual engagement.
4) We expect that scores on BESSI domains and facets will generally increase by participant grade level/age.
5) We expect that the BESSI domains will relate with student outcomes in a number of conceptually-meaningful ways. See the attached pdf for specific predictions.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is an observational study without any between-subject or within-subject manipulations.

q9.value: This observational study does not include multiple conditions. Therefore, the only element of randomization is that, for most measures, the item order is randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: CLRN expects a sample size of approximately 1,000 participants for this study.

q14.value: This sample size would provide 88.8% power to detect a small effect (r = .10), and greater than 99.9% power to detect a medium-sized (r = .30) or large  (r = .50) effect, using two-tailed tests at the .05

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above

question.value: This observational study does not include any manipulated variables.

The main predictors will be the 32 BESSI 1.0 facets, and the five expected domains derived from these facets.

The main outcomes will be life satisfaction (measured using Satisfaction With Life Scale); popularity (measured using an item from the Behavior Report Form); social status (measured using an item adapted from Anderson, John, Keltner, & Kring, 2001); friendship quality (measured using an abbreviated version of the Friendship Qualities Scale); romantic relationship satisfaction (measured using two items from the Dyadic Adjustment Scale); parental relationship quality (measured using six items adapted from the Dunedin Study); academic engagement measured using an abbreviated version of the Engagement versus Disaffection with Learning scale); exercise (measured using the Godin Leisure Time Exercise Questionnaire); volunteerism (measured using four items from Carlo, Okun, Knight, & de Guzman, 2005); and occupational interests (measured using the O*Net Mini Interest Profiler), as well as student information system data on attendance, report card grades, and discipline provided by the CLRN.

The main covariates are student grade level and gender.

The 32 BESSI facet scales will be scored from their constituent items using simple item aggregation. See the attached Excel file for a list of items and scale assignments.

Domain scales for the BESSI will be derived from principal components analyses (PCAs) and exploratory factor analyses (EFAs) of the BESSI facet scales. The assignment of facets to domains will depend on the PCA and EFA results, as well as conceptual considerations, and is therefore exploratory. However, all decisions about assigning the BESSI facets to domains will be made before we conduct any analyses to test associations between the BESSI scores and student outcomes. After assigning facets to domains, we will derive two sets of domain scores: one from simple aggregation of the facet scores, and one from factor scores for a selected PCA or EFA of the facet scales.

All outcome measures are previously published, and we will compute outcome scores following the published scoring instructions for each measure. For most outcome measures, scale scores are computed using simple item aggregation.

1) Internal consistency of the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Cronbach’s alpha reliability coefficient.
2) Differentiation between the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients.
3) The multidimensional structure of the BESSI will be tested using PCAs and EFAs of the 32 BESSI facet scales. These analyses will be repeated using both orthogonal (varimax) and oblique (promax) rotations.
4) Age differences in the BESSI domains and facets will be tested using one-way ANOVAs, with grade level as a fixed factor.
5) Associations of the BESSI domains with student outcomes will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients and multiple regression analyses. In the regression analyses, we will first analyze associations on a domain-by-domain basis, then all BESSI domains will be entered simultaneously as predictors. The correlation and regression analyses will be repeated both with and without gender and grade level as covariates.

q20.value: Number of disciplinary incidents may be transformed to reduce the influence of outliers. All decisions about whether and how to transform this variable will be made after examining its frequency distribution, but before testing its associations with the BESSI domains and facets.

q21.value: All tests will be two-tailed tests using the .05 significance level. To avoid interpreting statistically significant but trivially small effects, interpretation will focus on effect sizes (r/β) of .10 or greater.

q22.value: The study’s survey includes two pairs of attention-check items: one pair near the end of the BESSI, and one pair near the end of the outcome battery. Participants who fail either BESSI attention check item will be excluded from all analyses. Participants who pass both BESSI attention check items, but then fail either outcome attention check item, will be excluded from all analyses of the outcome measures.

q23.value: For participants who pass the relevant attention and completion checks, each missing response will be imputed as the sample’s mean response to that item, rounded to the nearest possible response option.

q24.value:
There may be individual differences in acquiescent response style on the BESSI. We will therefore examine whether accounting for these individual differences (e.g., using within-person centering or random-intercept EFA) affects the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We may use the PCA/EFA results to develop and test confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) models of the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We will examine possible gender differences in the BESSI domains and facets using independent-samples t-tests, as well as two-way ANOVAs with grade level and gender as fixed factors.

We will also examine relations of the BESSI facets with student outcomes using correlation and regression analyses. We will repeat these analyses both with and without grade level and gender as covariates.

attributes.title: Investigating the moderating effects of self-esteem, perseverative thinking and personality on a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity
attributes.description: Aiming to investigate whether a positive writing intervention can alleviate the subjective and cardiovascular effects of acute stress when completing a critical social evaluation task based on the trier social stress test (TSST). Additionally, we will investigate the extent to which the effect of this positive writing intervention on acute stress reactivity is moderated by individual differences, specifically: ratings of self-esteem, perseverative thinking, and personality type.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Investigating the moderating effects of self-esteem, perseverative thinking and personality on a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity.

We are aiming to investigate whether a positive writing intervention can alleviate the subjective and cardiovascular effects of acute stress when completing a critical social evaluation task based on the trier social stress test (TSST). Additionally, we will investigate the extent to which the effect of this positive writing intervention on acute stress reactivity is moderated by individual differences, specifically: ratings of self-esteem, perseverative thinking, and personality type.

other.value: Each of the moderators under investigation will feed into a separate MRes project. Thus, the analyses for each individual moderator will be reported individually.

sample.value: A sample size of 36 participants is required to observe large effects size at 0.8 power and an alpha level of 0.05. Therefore, 40 participants will be recruited to allow for 10% dropout and/or missing data. While we are only powered to observe large effects, we anticipate that some of the effects under investigation will be small-to-medium. However, within the constraints of the time available for data collection on this MRes project, we will not feasibly have the time to obtain a larger sample.

analyses.value:
A series of simple slopes analyses will be conducted. Separate analyses will be conducted for each moderator. Predictors will be the categorical variable ‘condition’ (positive writing vs. control writing, dummy coded as 1 and -1 respectively) and the moderators ‘perseverative thinking’, ‘self-esteem’ and ‘personality’. Separate analyses will be conducted for each outcome variable (HR, SBP, DBP, state anxiety), at each time point (separate ‘change from baseline’ scores will be calculated for reactivity to the writing task, speaking task and mental arithmetic task; recovery scores will also be calculated by subtracting the measures obtained ten minutes following mental arithmetic from the scores obtained at baseline).

An exploratory analysis using LIWC software will be ran on the final written pieces to investigate the percentage of positive words used in the text.

outliers.value: Exclusion criteria involves anyone under the age of 18. While participants with a current or past diagnosis of anxiety/stress disorders will not be excluded from the study, participants will be able to make an informed decision of whether they believe they can take part and will be made aware they are able to withdraw at any time. Extreme outliers (change scores for any of the DVs > 3.24 SD from the mean) will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable being measured for this study will be acute stress reactivity. The moderator variables being measured will be perseverative thinking, self-esteem and personality.

To measure acute stress reactivity, both physiological and self-report methods will be employed. Heart rate, systolic blood pressure and diastolic blood pressure will be used as markers of psychophysiological stress reactivity, and subjective self-reported anxiety will be recorded using a visual-analogue adaptation of the State-Trait Anxiety Questionnaire Short-Form (STAI-SF; Marteau & Bekker, 1992). 

The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Questionnaire (Rosenberg, 1965) will be used to measure self-esteem. 
The Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (Ehring, 2011) will be used to collect perseverative thinking scores. The Big Five Inventory 2- Short Form (Soto & John, 2017) will be used to collect scores for the big 5 personality traits; Openness, Extraversion, Neuroticism, Conscientiousness and Agreeableness, and their lower order facets. 

The questionnaires for self-esteem, perseverative thinking and personality will be sent to participants as part of an online survey after informed consent has been provided. Both physiological and self-reported stress will be collected at four intervals throughout the experimental stage: on arrival, after writing intervention, after participation in the critical social evaluation task and after a 10-minute cooldown period.

conditions.value:
There will be two conditions: a positive writing intervention for two minutes versus a control writing intervention for two minutes.

This duration is based on literature reporting that two minutes is the minimum length of time needed for a therapeutic writing task to produce the many psychological and physical health benefits as reported in by expressive and positive writing paradigms (King and Miner, 2000; Burton & King, 2007). In regard to testing an intervention that can be deemed a practical solution to the general population, 2 minutes may also be more adaptable to everyday life.

The positive writing condition will prompt participants to write about an extremely positive event that has occurred in their life. The instructions for the positive writing condition, in accordance with Smith et al. (2018) and King and Miner (2000), will be: 
•	‘For the next 2 minutes, I would like you to write your very deepest thoughts and feelings about the most intensely positive experience of your entire life or an extremely important positive issue that has affected you and your life. Really delve into it and focus on your thoughts and feelings surrounding the experience.’

The control condition will require participants to complete a mundane writing task. This is with the notion that a mundane writing activity will not induce any form of emotive response, nor have an effect on the participant’s stress-reaction. The instructions given will be: 
•	‘For the next two minutes, I would like you to describe the shoes you are currently wearing in as much detail and as objectively as possible.’

In conjunction with King and Miner’s (2000) protocol, in which they state that 2 minutes is sufficient for a writing intervention due to the writer’s continuous processing of the event afterwards, the participants will remain sitting for another 2 minutes before moving on to the next stage. This will replace the anticipation period used in the original TSST.

hypothesis.value:
The aim of this study is to investigate if a positive writing intervention can alleviate the subjective and cardiovascular effects of acute stress when completing a critical social evaluation task based on the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) ( Kirschbaum, Pirke & Hellhammer, 1993). Additionally, we will investigate the extent to which the effect of this positive writing intervention on acute stress reactivity is moderated by individual differences, specifically: ratings of self-esteem, perseverative thinking, and Big 5 personality traits.

With respect to each of the moderating variables under investigation:

i) It has been identified that there is a link between high self-esteem and a lower activation of psychological and physiological stress responses, (O’Donnell et al, 2008; Pruessner et al, 2005). It was found that when an individual reports having higher self-esteem, their physiological response, specifically cortisol production and heart-rate variability was considerably less activated in response to a stress task, compared to those with a lower self-esteem. It is therefore predicted that individuals who report higher self-esteem will also have lower overall stress reactivity in response to a critical social evaluation task. It is hypothesised that self-esteem will play a moderating role in the effects of a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity. Specifically, individuals with higher self-esteem, and who are in the intervention group, will have lower stress reactivity compared to individuals with lower-self-esteem in both conditions. 

ii) Stress reactivity has been linked to perseverative cognitions and thinking patterns. Perseverative thinking is described as continuous and repetitive negative thinking and includes processes such as worry, maladaptive brooding and rumination (Sorg et al., 2012). The perseverative thinking hypothesis suggests that stress and perseverative thinking interact, and those prone to this type of thinking are likely to suffer from negative health outcomes (Brosschot et al., 2006; Kelly, 2018). Some studies have found that perseverative thinking can moderate the effects of a writing intervention for physical health issues (O’Connor et al., 2011), however, it is unknown if perseverative thinking moderates the therapeutic effect of positive writing on acute stress reactivity. It is hypothesised that perseverative thinking, as measured by the Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (PTQ) (Ehring et al., 2011), will have a moderating effect on a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity. Specifically, those who have high scores of perseverative thinking will experience both greater levels of stress when presented with a critical social evaluation task, and less benefit from the implementation of a positive writing intervention.

iii) There is evidence showing that personality traits influence the coping strategies we choose to deal with stressful experiences; which may be adaptive or maladaptive (Dumitru & Cozman, 2012). Some Big 5 personality traits have been found to be adaptive, for example individuals high on extraversion and conscientiousness are less vulnerable to stress than those high on neuroticism (Vollrath et al, 2000). It is important to know if some personality traits are more resilient to the adverse effects of stress and anxiety, but there is a lack of research looking at the lower order facets of the Big 5. These are six subcategories of each of the five personality traits that provide a much ‘richer description’ of a person’s personality (Costa & McCrae, 1995), in order to get a deeper understanding of aspects of personality which influence a person’s stress response. It is hypothesized that those who score low for facets of extraversion will experience greater levels of subjective and cardiovascular stress reactivity. Due to this it is expected that these individuals will show greater benefits from a positive writing intervention. Specifically, individuals low on extraversion in the positive writing condition will elicit less of a stress response than individuals low on extraversion in the control writing condition. It is also hypothesized that those who score high on facets of neuroticism will experience greater levels of subjective and cardiovascular stress reactivity in response to a critical social evaluation task. Predicated by research which has suggested that positive writing interventions (e.g. written benefit finding) are most beneficial for individuals with high levels of negative affect (e.g. trait anxiety; e.g. Danoff Burg et al., 2006), it is expected that a positive writing intervention will be more beneficial for individuals with high neuroticism.

It is therefore predicted that individuals who report higher self-esteem will also have lower overall stress reactivity in response to a critical social evaluation task. It is hypothesised that self-esteem will play a moderating role in the effects of a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity. Specifically, individuals with higher self-esteem, and who are in the intervention group, will have lower stress reactivity compared to individuals with lower-self-esteem in both conditions. 

ii) Stress reactivity has been linked to perseverative cognitions and thinking patterns. Perseverative thinking is described as continuous and repetitive negative thinking and includes processes such as worry, maladaptive brooding and rumination (Sorg et al., 2012). The perseverative thinking hypothesis suggests that stress and perseverative thinking interact, and those prone to this type of thinking are likely to suffer from negative health outcomes (Brosschot et al., 2006; Kelly, 2018). Some studies have found that perseverative thinking can moderate the effects of a writing intervention for physical health issues (O’Connor et al., 2011), however, it is unknown if perseverative thinking moderates the therapeutic effect of positive writing on acute stress reactivity. It is hypothesised that perseverative thinking, as measured by the Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (PTQ) (Ehring et al., 2011), will have a moderating effect on a positive writing intervention for acute stress reactivity. Specifically, those who have high scores of perseverative thinking will experience both greater levels of stress when presented with a critical social evaluation task, and less benefit from the implementation of a positive writing intervention.

iii) There is evidence showing that personality traits influence the coping strategies we choose to deal with stressful experiences; which may be adaptive or maladaptive (Dumitru & Cozman, 2012). Some Big 5 personality traits have been found to be adaptive, for example individuals high on extraversion and conscientiousness are less vulnerable to stress than those high on neuroticism (Vollrath et al, 2000). It is important to know if some personality traits are more resilient to the adverse effects of stress and anxiety, but there is a lack of research looking at the lower order facets of the Big 5. These are six subcategories of each of the five personality traits that provide a much ‘richer description’ of a person’s personality (Costa & McCrae, 1995), in order to get a deeper understanding of aspects of personality which influence a person’s stress response. It is hypothesized that those who score low for facets of extraversion will experience greater levels of subjective and cardiovascular stress reactivity. Due to this it is expected that these individuals will show greater benefits from a positive writing intervention. Specifically, individuals low on extraversion in the positive writing condition will elicit less of a stress response than individuals low on extraversion in the control writing condition. It is also hypothesized that those who score high on facets of neuroticism will experience greater levels of subjective and cardiovascular stress reactivity in response to a critical social evaluation task. Predicated by research which has suggested that positive writing interventions (e.g. written benefit finding) are most beneficial for individuals with high levels of negative affect (e.g. trait anxiety; e.g. Danoff Burg et al., 2006), it is expected that a positive writing intervention will be more beneficial for individuals with high neuroticism.

attributes.title: Separating conceptual priming from perceptual priming and stimulus-response learning
attributes.description: It is likely that both component processes and stimulus-response (S-R) learning contribute to priming and repetition suppression (RS). However, questions concerning S-R learning remain and we aim to distinguish the neural correlates of perceptual and conceptual components of priming, and S-R learning in the current investigation. The first purpose is to separate conceptual priming from perceptual priming and S-R learning. We will test if any region shows RS in a condition without perceptual overlap and without facilitation by S-R binding. Second, we will compare the amount of priming and RS in “orthogonal” approach with “changing referent” approach. We aim to answer whether two orthogonal conceptual tasks that access different semantic information can still cause conceptual priming and RS. Finally, we aim to replicate the findings that showed perceptual RS in the right fusiform gyrus (FG) and S-R learning in the right inferior frontal gyrus (IFG).

attributes.title: Increasing the relative availability of healthier vs. less-healthy food: Exploring the role of social norms

q1.value: Increasing the relative availability of healthier vs. less-healthy food: Exploring the role of social norms

q2.value: Rachel Pechey, Natasha Clarke, Emily Pechey, Minna Ventsel, Gareth J Hollands, Theresa Marteau

q3.value:
Increasing the relative availability of healthier and more plant-based foods increases the likelihood that they are selected. The mechanisms by which this intervention has its effect are little explored. The aim of the two studies described here is to provide the first exploration of the role of perceived popularity – as a marker of descriptive social norms – as a possible mechanism underlying the effects of availability interventions. 
Study 1 examines the extent to which altering the availability of healthier food impacts on its perceived popularity. 
Study 2 examines the extent to which implying differential popularity for healthier (over less-healthy) foods alters healthier food selection.

Online Study
Primary Research Questions:
1.	To what extent does the relative availability of healthier vs. less-healthy foods impact on perceived popularity of these products?
2.	To what extent does manipulating the fullness of shelves displaying available items impact on perceived popularity of these products?

Secondary Research Questions:
3.	To what extent does the perceived popularity of healthier vs. less-healthy foods alter the selection of healthier foods?
4.	To what extent does manipulating availability at the product-level (i.e. the number of units of a product) rather than the category-level (i.e. the number of unique products) alter the impact of relative availability on selection of healthier foods?

Lab Study
To what extent does the popularity implied by the relative availability of healthier vs. less-healthy foods alter the impact of changing the availability of healthier foods?

q4.value:
Online Study
1.	Increased availability of healthier (less-healthy) foods increases the perceived popularity of healthier (less-healthy) foods – when shelves are full
2.	When shelves are emptier, decreased availability of healthier (less-healthy) foods decreases the perceived popularity of healthier (less-healthy) foods
3.	Increased perceived popularity of healthier (less-healthy) foods increases selection of healthier (less-healthy) foods
4.	Manipulating availability at the product-level will have a smaller impact than manipulating availability at the category-level

Lab Study
Increased availability of healthier (less-healthy) foods increases selection of healthier (less-healthy) foods when in line with perceived popularity (i.e. when offered a full tray), but this impact is countered when perceived popularity acts against increased availability (i.e. when tray is emptier)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Online Study
Mixed design, with 3x2 between-subjects conditions (3 availability conditions x 2 shelf fullness conditions), and one within-subjects condition (manipulation level)

Lab study
Between-subjects design, with 4 groups (2 availability conditions x 2 tray fullness conditions)

q9.value:
Online Study
Participants will be randomised to one of the six between-subjects groups (3 availability conditions x 2 shelf fullness conditions) for each of the study trials (4 product-level manipulation trials and 4 category-level manipulation trials)

Lab Study
Participants will be randomised to one of the four study groups (2 availability conditions x 2 tray fullness conditions)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Online Study
Participants will be a sample of 2340 UK adults, recruited from an online panel run by a market research agency. The sample will have quotas set for gender and socioeconomic status (based on highest educational qualification). 
Inclusion criteria are that participants must be currently residing in the UK, and be at least 18 years old. 
In addition, participants must correctly answer a quality control question as part of the study to ensure that they are paying attention to the questions. Anyone answering incorrectly will be screened out and will not be counted towards the study quotas.
Participants are paid at the standard rate for the market research panel for their time spent completing the survey. 

Lab Study
UK adults, recruited from a market research agency. The study will aim to recruit comparable numbers of men and women, and comparable numbers of participants with no A-levels or equivalent (categorised as lower education) and two or more A-levels (higher education). Those who are studying for A-levels will be excluded from participation.

q13.value:
Online Study
Participants will be a sample of 2340 UK adults. 

Lab Study
Participants will be 279 UK adults

q14.value:
Online Study
Sample size calculations allowed for a minimum of four trials (photos of food/drink displays), with large variability of level-1 residuals and level-1 coefficient (both set to 2), and a small-medium standardised effect size (d=0.27 – equating to half the difference observed between the equal numbers of healthier and less-healthy options and predominantly less-healthy options conditions in a previous laboratory story (Pechey, Sexton, Codling, & Marteau, in submission)). The Optimal Design sample size calculator, set to alpha of 0.01 (to adjust for multiple comparisons) and with power of 0.8, suggested a sample size of 772 (i.e. 386 per group). Accounting for the six groups (3x2 availability by shelf-fullness conditions) gives a final sample size of 2316, rounded to 2340 to allow for some missing data.

Lab Study
This is an add-on to an existing study, with sample size (n=279) having being determined for that study (Clarke et al: Size and shape of plates and size of wine glasses and bottles: impact on selection of food and alcohol). Power calculations were conducted using G*Power (3.1.9.2), to determine power in a logistic regression to replicate the effect of availability found in (Pechey et al., in submission) – i.e. the effect of availability when greater consumption by others would be implied for options with more units remaining (half the conditions in the current study). Calculations were based on a sample size of 139 (i.e. half the sample) for a 2-group comparison with participants equally divided between groups, and an alpha of 0.025 to adjust for investigating two main effects. R-squared from other X (0.025) and the baseline proportion choosing a healthier option (21%; from the predominantly less-healthy condition) were taken from Pechey et al. (in submission). This sample size would give us a power of 0.81 to detect an effect equating to the change in the proportion of healthier options selected to match that found in the equal numbers of healthier and less-healthy options condition in Pechey et al. (44%) – and a power of 0.99 if this change is equivalent to the proportion of healthier options chosen in the predominantly healthier condition in Pechey et al (66%) (one-tailed).

question.value:
Online Study
Availability: This will be manipulated by showing participants photos of shelves that vary in the relative availability of healthier and less-healthy options: 75% healthier & 25% less healthy; 50% healthier & 50% less healthy; 25% healthier & 75% less-healthy.

Shelf fullness: Foods will either be displayed on a fuller shelf (same number of units of products in each facing) or emptier shelf (varied number of units of products in each facing, with maximum number of units equal to that in fuller shelf condition)

Manipulation level: Whether availability is manipulated at the category-level (i.e. changing brands) or product-level (i.e. number of units of a particular brand)


Lab Study
Availability: This will be manipulated by offering participants snacks on trays that vary in the relative availability of healthier and less-healthy options: 2/3rds healthier & 1/3rd less healthy; 1/3rd healthier & 2/3rds less-healthy.

Tray fullness: Foods will either be displayed on a fuller tray (same number of units of products in each facing) or emptier tray (varied number of units of products in each facing, with the same number of units as in fuller shelf condition)

Online Study
Outcome measures:
Primary: Perceived percentage of sales of healthier (over less-healthy) products
Secondary: Selection of healthier (over less-healthy) products

Predictors:
Socioeconomic status: Two indicators: Highest educational qualification (no A-levels or equivalent: lower education; two or more A-levels: higher education); Household income

Demographics: Gender, age, hunger (7-pt rating scale from Very hungry – Very full).

Lab Study
Outcome measure:
Selection of food (healthier or less healthy) from tray 

Predictors:
Socioeconomic status: Highest educational qualification (no A-levels or equivalent: lower education; two or more A-levels: higher education)

Demographics: Gender, age.

Online Study
Primary Analysis	
Multilevel regression predicting the perceived percentage of healthier (over less-healthy) item sales from ranges with (i) 75% healthier and 25% less-healthy products, and (ii) 25% healthier and 75% less-healthy products, compared to 50% healthier and 50% less-healthy products, when shelves are (a) full and (b) half-empty, with interactions between availability and shelf-fullness, and random effects by participant.
Covariates: Age, gender, education, hunger, manipulation-level, food type.

To answer Research Questions 1 and 2:
1.	To what extent does the relative availability of healthier vs. less-healthy foods impact on perceived popularity of these products?
Look at coefficient for availability condition in analysis above [equivalent to effect of availability in shelves-full condition]

2.	To what extent does manipulating the fullness of shelves displaying available items impact on perceived popularity of these products?
Look at coefficients for shelf fullness, and interaction between shelf-fullness and availability condition in analysis above

Secondary Analyses
To answer Research Question 3:
3.	To what extent does the perceived popularity of healthier vs. less-healthy foods alter the selection of healthier foods?

Multilevel logistic regression predicting the selection of healthier foods from the perceived purchases of healthier vs. less-healthy foods by others. Analyses will be conducted with random effects by participant.	
	
Covariates: Age, gender, education, hunger, food type.

To answer Research Question 4:
4.	To what extent does manipulating availability at the product-level (i.e. the number of units of a product) rather than the category-level (i.e. the number of unique products) alter the impact of relative availability on selection of healthier foods?

Multilevel logistic regression predicting the selection of healthier foods from ranges with (i) 75% healthier and 25% less-healthy products, and (ii) 25% healthier and 75% less-healthy products, compared to 50% healthier and 50% less-healthy products, with interactions by manipulation-level. Analyses will be conducted for full-shelf trials only, with random effects by participant.	

Covariates: Age, gender, education, hunger, food type.

Lab Study
Logistic regression predicting whether or not participants selected a healthier snack option (participants who declined to take a snack will be excluded from this analysis). Key predictors will be availability condition, implied popularity condition and their interaction. Covariates will be age, gender and education. 

Secondary analysis: Was there a difference in declining to select a snack by condition?
Logistic regression predicting whether or not participants selected a snack from availability and implied popularity conditions, with covariates as above.

q20.value:
Online Study
Availability condition will be dummy coded so that the reference group is 50% healthier and 50% less-healthy, with two dummy variables indicating (1) 25% healthier and 75% less-healthy products, (2) 75% healthier and 25% less-healthy products.
Shelf-fullness will be dummy coded so that 0=shelves full, 1=shelves-half-empty
Manipulation-level will be dummy coded so that 0=category-level, 1=product-level
Food type will be identified using a factor variable.
Socioeconomic indicator groupings will be:
Highest educational qualification: two categories: no A-levels or equivalent (lower education); two or more A-levels (higher education)
Household income: (1) Up to £17,499 per year; (2) £17,500-£29,999 per year; (3) £30,000-£49,999 per year; (4) £50,000 or more per year

Lab Study
Availability condition will be dummy coded so that 0= 25% healthier and 75% less-healthy products, 1= 75% healthier and 25% less-healthy products.
Tray-fullness will be dummy coded so that 0=tray full, 1=tray emptier
Highest educational qualification: two categories: no A-levels or equivalent (lower education); two or more A-levels (higher education)

q21.value:
Online Study
For our main analyses, we will use p<0.05 (two-tailed) to infer that there is a statistically significant effect.
For the remaining analyses (secondary analyses: Research Questions 3 and 4) we will use a p-value <0.005 (two-tailed), using a Bonferroni correction to account for the different hypotheses to be tested (p=0.05/9).

Lab Study
For our main analyses, we will use p<0.05 (two-tailed) to infer that there is a statistically significant effect.
For our secondary analysis, we will use a p-value <0.008 (two-tailed), using a Bonferroni correction to account for the different hypotheses to be tested (p=0.05/6).

q22.value:
Online Study
Speeders: Anyone completing the survey in less than 30% of the median time will be excluded.

Lab Study
Participants who decline to take a snack will not be included in the Primary analysis

q23.value:
Online Study
Missing data will be coded as such. No replacement or imputation will be used. 
Participants who do not complete the full survey will not count towards the survey quota, and will not be included in the analysis.

Lab Study
Participants who decline to take a snack will not be included in the Primary analysis, but will contribute to the secondary analysis

attributes.title: Benevolent and hostile behavior in a competitive setting: The influence of gender

q1.value: Benevolent and hostile behavior in a competitive setting: The influence of gender

q2.value: Jenna Weingarten , Keana Richards, Coren Apicella

q3.value: This experiment will examine men’s responses following competitive wins and losses to male and female opponents in a sham competition. Both competition outcome (IV1, winning or losing) and opponent gender (IV2, male or female) will be randomized. For our primary dependent variable, we will measure how much money male participants transfer to (or away from) their opponents following a competition. We also measure benevolent and hostile sexism attitudes using two two-item responses, respectively.

q4.value:
Primary Hypotheses

1.	We will examine how competition outcome (winning/losing) and opponent gender (male/female) influence the amount of money participants transfer to (or away from) their opponents. We predict that competition outcome will interact with opponent gender to influence how much money is transferred to (or away) from opponents. Specifically, we predict that men who win the competition will transfer more money to female opponents than to male opponents (i.e. benevolent sexism) and men who lose the competition will transfer more money away from female opponents than male opponents (i.e. hostile sexism). We also predict a main effect of competition outcome, such that winners will transfer more money to their opponents than losers. See Figure 2 under Analysis Plan for the direction of anticipated results.  

2.	We will ask participants to predict the outcome of the study to qualify folk beliefs about sexist behavior. We predict participants will state that men who win the competition will give more money to female (than male) opponents. We also predict participants will state that men who lose the competition will remove more money from female (than male) opponents. 

Exploratory Hypotheses 

1.	We will explore how competition outcome (winning/losing) and opponent gender (male/female) affect self-reported benevolent sexist attitudes. We predict no main effect of competition outcome or gender on strength of benevolent sexism. We predict that competition outcome will interact with opponent gender to influence the strength of self-reported benevolent sexism. Specifically, we predict that competition outcome will affect benevolent sexist attitudes when the opponent is female but not male, such that participants who win against women will report stronger benevolent sexism and those who lose to women will report lowered benevolent sexism. 

2.	We will explore how competition outcome and opponent gender affect self-reported hostile sexist attitudes. We predict no main effect of competition outcome or gender opponent on strength of hostile sexism. However, we predict that competition outcome will interact with opponent gender to influence the strength of self-reported hostile sexism. Specifically, competition outcome will affect hostile sexist attitudes when the opponent is female but not male; such that participants who win against women will have lower hostile sexism and those who lose to women will report stronger hostile sexism.  

3.	We will explore the relationship between benevolent and hostile aggression and the amount of money transferred to opponents. We predict an interaction between competition outcome and the amount of money transferred such that in winners, higher benevolent sexism will be associated with more money given to women relative to men, and in losers, hostile sexism will result in less money given to women relative to men. 

4.	We will explore the relationship between benevolent and hostile sexism, controlling for competition outcome. We predict that men with high scores on the item of benevolent sexism will have high scores on the item of hostile sexism. 

5.	We will explore perceived stereotypes of the counting task to determine if participants believe the task favors men or women. Controlling for competition result, we predict the participants will not perceive the task as female- or male-oriented.

question.value:
We will employ a between-subject design with four conditions (win against male opponent, win against female opponent, lose against male opponent, lose against female opponent). All participants will compete for the same amount of money (the chance to earn 20 cents) in the competition. Participants will be matched to a male or female avatar, and this avatar will be their opponent throughout the study. The opponent is a computer, but the participants will believe that their opponent is a real person who already completed the study. We will tell the participants that their winning or losing competition result is determined by how well the participant does compared to their opponent’s past performance.    

Because we are interested in how much money participants will transfer to (or away from) their opponent following the competition, we will control for potential income effects in our design. To do this, prior to the competition, participants will perform an extremely simple “practice” task that virtually guarantees them a balance of either 10 cents or 30 cents (depending on randomization) for the same specified number of successfully completed problems. Those assigned to earn 10 cents will always win the competition by three points, and those assigned to 30 cents will always lose the competition by three points. Thus, our design allows winners and losers to compete for the same amount of money (20 cents) and end the competition with the same amount of money in the bank (30 cents). The schematic of the experimental design is shown in Figure 1. 

Following the competition, participants will have the opportunity to decide how much money we give or take from their opponent. We will tell them that they have been randomly assigned to receive a bonus of 5 cents. As part of their bonus, they will have the opportunity to choose how much money we give to or take from their opponent (up to +/- 10 cents, in 1-cent increments). Their own payment is unaffected by their choice. We chose this design to ensure that their decision to help or harm their opponent is unrelated to any desire to keep the money for themselves. 

Following the study, participants will be paid their five-cent bonus and the bonus payment (30 cents or 50 cents) they would have received if they had won the competition. This is in addition to the 60 cents they are guaranteed for participating in the study.

One condition of the full Qualtrics study design is shown in Document 1.

question.value:
Opponent Gender: Gender is manipulated through the use of avatars. Participants will choose their own avatar from one of three male avatar choices. They will then be randomly matched to 1 of 6 opponent avatars (that are distinct from the participant avatar choices). Three of the opponent avatars are male, and three of the opponent avatars are female. We will present the opponent avatar throughout the competition to keep the opponent’s gender salient. Participants will be asked their opponent’s gender at the conclusion of the study, and they will be incentivized to answer correctly.

Competition Outcome: Participants will compete in a sham “counting game” for 20 cents and will be randomized to win or lose. Participants will start the competition with either 10 cents or 30 cents (depending on randomization from their simple practice task). Participants assigned to the 10-cent group will always win the competition (earning 20 cents), and participants assigned to the 30-cent group will always lose the competition (earning 0 cents). Winners will be told that they won by 3 points, and losers will be told that they lost by 3 points. All participants will finish the competition with 30 cents.

Amount Transferred: The main dependent variable is a continuous measure where participants can choose to remove up to 10 cents or give up to 10 cents to their opponent for a bonus payment. They will be shown a slider scale from -10 to 10 that changes in 1 cent increments. The amount transferred will be our measure of monetary benevolence/hostility. 

Benevolent Sexism: Benevolent sexism refers to favorable attitudes toward women that incorporate the belief that women should be idealized and protected. Participants will rate the degree to which they agree with the following two statements on a 5-point Likert scale: Men need to cherish and protect women and Every man ought to have a woman he adores. We will add the ratings on the two items. A higher score indicates a stronger benevolent sexist attitude. 

Hostile Sexism: Hostile sexism refers to negative evaluations of women. We will measure hostile sexism by having participants rate the degree to which they agree with the following two statements on a 5-point Likert scale: In most things, men are better than women and Women seek to gain power by getting control over women. We will add the ratings on the two items. A higher score denotes a stronger hostile sexist attitude. 

Deception check: Following the participant decision to take or give money to their opponent, participants will see: What do you think this study was about? The question is open-ended.  

Task Stereotypes: To assess perceived stereotypes of the task, we will ask participants: You just completed our counting competition. In general, who do you think is more likely to win? Participants will choose a) Men, b) Women, c) Both. 

Participant Predictions: To assess participant beliefs about benevolent sexism, we will ask participants: Do you think men who win the competition will a) give more money to female opponents, b) give more money to male opponents, or c) no difference. To assess participant beliefs about hostile sexism, we will ask participants: Do you think men who lose the competition will a) remove more money from female opponents, b) remove more money from male opponents, or c) no difference. We will also ask participants about their attitudes toward losing to a woman.

Primary Hypothesis 1: We will first run two separate independent sample T-tests, comparing 1) the amount transferred to male vs female opponents in participants who won the competition and 2) comparing the amount transferred to male vs female opponents in participants who lost the competition. We will then employ regression analyses to model the relationships between competition outcome, gender opponent, and the interaction between competition outcome and gender opponent, on the amount of money transferred to opponent.

Primary Hypothesis 2: We will employ a Chi-Square goodness of fit test to determine if participants predict hostile and benevolent sexism at a greater probability than chance.

q21.value: All interactions will be tested by including the product of the variables as an additional variable in regression models. Interactions will be considered significant when coefficients differ significantly from 0. Alpha levels will be set to .05 for all analyses.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants who 1) indicated that they were female once beginning the study. We will also exclude participants who 2) were unable to correctly identify the gender of their opponent following the competition. We will exclude participants who 3) answered 8 or more of the questions incorrectly on the pretest or 4) put down the same answer for each question on the pretest. These participants will know that they did not deserve the bonus money they received, and the deception in the study will be obvious to them. 

We will exclude participants who 5) put the same number down for every question during the competition phase or 6) did not answer more than 5 questions correctly during the competition phase. This would indicate that they were not taking the study and competition seriously, which would not allow us to determine the impact of winning/losing on aggression across gender. We will exclude participants who 7) guessed the hypothesis or purpose of the study (i.e., the influence of competition outcome on how people treat men versus women.

q24.value:
Exploratory Hypothesis 1: We will employ regression analyses to model the relationships between competition outcome, gender opponent and the interaction between competition outcome and gender opponent, on benevolent sexism. 

Exploratory Hypothesis 2: We will employ regression analyses to model the relationships between competition outcome, gender opponent and the interaction between competition outcome and gender opponent, on hostile sexism. 

Exploratory Hypothesis 3: We will employ regression analyses to test the interactions between competition outcome and hostile and benevolent sexism on the amount of money transferred to male and female opponents.

Exploratory Hypothesis 4: We will employ regression analyses to model the relationships between hostile sexism and benevolent sexism, controlling for competition outcome.
